content:
re : I have transferred from Windows 10 to Windows 11

Do you mean you had a computer using Windows 10 and you have used the upgrade option to change to Windows 11 ? OR do you mean you have two computers, old one using Windows 10 and new one using Windows 11 ?

Did you need to reinstall Thunderbird? If yes, where did you get the download/installation of thunderbird ? This is important because the official website download from this link: https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/ would put the Profile in an easy accessible default location as mentioned in all the various Help Articles etc , but if you got the latest Thunderbird via the Windows App Store then it gets more complicated as Windows stores everything in a completely different location.

Did Thunderbird ask you to create a mail account? If yes, this tells me you are using a new profile. This info combined with previous question would tell me where it got created.

In Windows C drive, do you see a folder called 'windows.old' ? If yes - click on it to see the contents do you see this 'Thunderbird' folder this in that location:

  • C:/Users/Username/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird

Does that 'Thunderbird' folder contain 'Profiles' folder which has profile name folders that contain abook.sqlite files of good size ? Does the 'ImapMail' or 'Mail' folder contain mail account name folders ?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
You can delete the files and folders using Windows File Explorer, while Thunderbird is shut down.

Go to Help > Troubleshooting Information > Profile Folder > click the button to the right to open Windows File Explorer at the profile location > find Mail\Local Folders.

You will find the files and folders there.
creator: wsmwk

content: If you are referring to columns in the message list pane, just highlight a column and drag left or right.
